node.title: Comment: A very Good Friday for Super Rugby Pacific
node.description: Comment - If there was ever evidence of a game living up to the hype, it was Friday night's blockbuster between the Blues and Crusaders. Video

node.title: Head of Arise Church resigns board seat following allegations
node.description: The founding pastor of one of the country's biggest pentecostal churches has resigned from its board amid controversy.

node.title: Black Ferns coach Glenn Moore announces resignation
node.description: Black Ferns Coach Glenn Moore has announced his resignation, days after a scathing review into team management and culture.

node.title: Russia claims its forces have cleared most of Mariupol
node.description: Russian missile strikes hit Ukraine's capital Kyiv and other cities on Saturday, as Moscow said its troops had cleared the urban area of Mariupol.

node.title: Hat-tricks and protests at Old Trafford
node.description: Cristiano Ronaldo starred as Manchester United won in the English Premier League amid scenes of fan protest at Old Trafford.

node.title: Air NZ deals with flood of phone calls as borders reopen
node.description: Air New Zealand has been dealing with a flood of phone calls from customers wanting information as the borders reopen.

node.title: Full transcript of "Face the Nation" on April 17, 2022
node.description: On this "Face the Nation" broadcast, Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba and Sen. Chris Coons join Margaret Brennan.

node.title: Container ship finally freed after being stuck in Chesapeake Bay for weeks
node.description: The Ever Forward was refloated just before 7 a.m. Sunday by two barges and five tugboats.

node.title: Transcript: Sister Norma Pimentel on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Sister Norma Pimentel, the executive director of the Catholic Charities of Rio Grande Valley, that aired Sunday, April 17, 2022, on "Face the Nation."

node.title: Full transcript: World Food Programme chief David Beasley on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with David Beasley, head of the World Food Programme, that aired Sunday, April 17, 2022, on "Face the Nation."

node.title: Ukraine's top diplomat says Mariupol "doesn't exist anymore"
node.description: "The situation in Mariupol is both dire militarily and heartbreaking," Kuleba said.

node.title: Transcript: Ret. Lt. Gen. Ben Hodges on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with retired Lt. Gen. Ben Hodges, the former commanding general of the U.S. Army in Europe, that aired Sunday, April 17, 2022, on "Face the Nation."

node.title: Transcript: Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba that aired Sunday, April 17, 2022, on "Face the Nation."

node.title: Transcript: Sen. Chris Coons on "Face the Nation"
node.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Democratic Sen. Chris Coons of Delaware that aired Sunday, April 17, 2022, on "Face the Nation."

node.title: SpaceX launches secret government payload
node.description: No details about the spy satellite payload were revealed, but the NRO declared mission success in a statement.

node.title: Global COVID relief "critical" to U.S. national security, Coons says
node.description: Senate Republicans blocked a deal providing $10 billion in COVID-19 relief from moving forward earlier this month.

node.title: An Easter prayer: The power of peace to create a more just world
node.description: Sharon Kugler, University Chaplain at Yale, on the importance of addressing aggression, poverty, ignorance and violence that oppresses and destroys our human family.

node.title: A Passover prayer: We must use our freedom to liberate the oppressed
node.description: Steve Leder, senior rabbi of Wilshire Boulevard Temple in Los Angeles, reminds us of the human imperative to alleviate suffering around the world.

node.title: Inside the Latter-day Saints' Washington, D.C. temple
node.description: For decades the towering marble edifice at our nation's capital has posed a mystery to those outside the faith. Now, after a major renovation, a public open house will welcome all to visit a building dedicated to reverence and contemplation.

node.title: Billy Crystal back on Broadway as "Mr. Saturday Night"
node.description: In 1992 the comedian directed his first movie, about an abrasive, 73-year-old washed-up comic. Now, thirty years later, Crystal has turned the film into a musical â€“ and the 74-year-old finally gets to act his age.

node.title: Suing over climate change: Taking fossil fuel companies to court
node.description: With the expense of mitigating the effects of climate change becoming more onerous, more than two dozen cities, counties and states are suing more than 40 fossil fuel companies, accusing them of making false and misleading claims about climate change.

node.title: The mystery of Francis Hines, and a dumpster full of art treasures
node.description: In 2017 a barn cleanout in Connecticut revealed a treasure trove of paintings by an obscure expressionist artist who'd also experimented with wrapping buildings and objects. Now, experts say the dumpster art by Francis Hines could be worth millions.

node.title: Delia Ephron on love, cancer, and a second chance
node.description: The author-screenwriter, no stranger to romantic storylines, has lately been living one: having lost her first husband, she married a man she'd first dated half a century ago. But their wedding occurred in the hospital, where she was undergoing chemotherapy for leukemia.

node.title: U.S. arms to Ukraine: Is it enough?
node.description: The Biden administration has ratcheted up its shipments of weapons, ammunition, body armor, and other equipment to Ukraine to defend against Russia's onslaught. But is it sufficient? And will a 21st century Berlin Airlift will be needed?

node.title: Righting wrongs: How Joyce Watkins was exonerated in court
node.description: More than three decades after she and her boyfriend were wrongly convicted in the death of her four-year-old great-niece, an unusual partnership of prosecutors and defense attorneys brought about what the now-74-year-old Watkins has long prayed for: exoneration.

node.title: Easter stories from the 60 Minutes Archive
node.description: Our favorite Easter Sunday stories from Andy Rooney, Harry Reasoner, and Morley Safer from the archives of 60 Minutes

node.title: Police arrest suspect in South Carolina mall shooting that injured 14
node.description: Jewayne Price, who was one of three people initially detained by law enforcement as a person of interest, is expected to be charged.

node.title: Ukraine remains defiant as key port city of Mariupol teeters on the brink
node.description: The battered port city of Mariupol appeared close to falling to Russian forces Sunday after seven weeks under siege.

node.title: The Book Report: Washington Post critic Ron Charles (April 17)
node.description: Recommendations from our book reviewer of new fiction and non-fiction titles for the spring.

node.title: Book excerpt: "Young Mungo" by Douglas Stuart
node.description: The Booker Prize-winning author of "Shuggie Bain" returns with a devastating novel about a 15-year-old boy in a violently homophobic community.
